subject: Re: [junit] Re: Is it possible to include javadoc/comments in junitreports?
msgSnippet: ... Aha. I am wondering why upper management types are reading low-level programmer tests. Why do they want to read those tests? I am concerned with the
messageBody:
valerie_abelin wrote:

>
> > I'm not sure how to do that. Typically, the name of the test is enough
> > to describe what each test means. Why is that not the case for you?
>
> I'd like to share the result of my unit testing with upper
> management-type people. testInsertTooLargeValue() doesn't mean much
> to them. I'd like a prose description like: "In this test, we try
> inserting a value into the table that is too large. Depending on such
> and such, this should occur. Or if not, then this should occur. In
> either case, the code finally handlings this use case in blah blah
> blah manner."

Aha. I am wondering why upper management types are reading low-level
programmer tests. Why do they want to read those tests?

I am concerned with the expense of manually duplicating your test code
in prose. If I knew what information they wanted, perhaps I could
suggest an alternative that is equally valuable to them, but much less
prone to error than translating code into English by hand.

Have you looked at Fit or FitNesse?
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
